title: How does a DVD player differentiate between CD and DVD? - Quora

response.answer_text: I can’t answer the question authoritatively, but pardon while I don my “bull hockey” hat and give it a shot. The data on either disk format has periodic error checking parity bits. Little bits of data you can use to confirm that what you just read was correct. Imagine reading a book where after each sentence the number of words in the sentence was printed. If you read a sentence with 10 words, but 11 were supposed to be there you might know something was up. Read up on CRC if you’re interested Cyclic redundancy check - Wikipedia I believe that audio CDs specifically use this. CD-ROM (aka data CDs probably use something different, but similar) Cross-interleaved Reed–Solomon coding - Wikipedia When using the wrong wavelength you’d get nothing nothing but errors, leading the player to quickly attempt to use the other wavelength.
